lesson.name: Part 1: What Is Critical Thinking and Why is it so Important?

page.title: Definition 1
page.contents:
Read each definition and reflect on how similar it is to your own ideas about critical thinking.

Is the definition somewhat similar, very similar, different, or very different from your own?

"Critical thinking is the intellectually disciplined process of actively and skillfully conceptualizing, applying, analyzing, synthesizing, and/or evaluating information gathered from, or generated by, observation, experience, reflection, reasoning, or communication, as a guide to belief and action."

The Critical Thinking Community

page.title: Definition 2
page.contents:
"Critical thinking requires disciplined thinking that is open-minded, rational, and informed by evidence in order to arrive at decisions or conclusions that go beyond factual recall. [Critical thinking] skills involve actively applying thinking strategies that range from analyzing relationships between components to drawing conclusions from a variety of data."

(ATLAS, 2013)

page.title: Definition 3
page.contents:
"Critical thinking is a term used by educators to describe forms of learning, thought, and analysis that go beyond the memorization and recall of information and facts. In common usage, critical thinking is an umbrella term that may be applied to many different forms of learning acquisition or to a wide variety of thought processes. In its most basic expression, critical thinking occurs when students are analyzing, evaluating, interpreting, or synthesizing information and applying creative thought to form an argument, solve a problem, or reach a conclusion."

The Glossary of Educational Reform

page.title: Refining Your Image of Critical Thinking
page.contents:
Now reflect on the similarities and differences between your concept map and the definitions of critical thinking that you read. What stood out for you in the definitions that you hadn't considered? What, if anything, do you want to add to your concept map? If you viewed any others, what, if anything, was missing in others' definitions?

Share your responses to this activity in your Community of Practice, or with your colleagues on the LINCS discussion forum.

page.title: Critical Thinking as Part of More Rigorous Instruction
page.contents:
If you did not complete Unit 1 in this module and would like to learn more about the rationale for increasing the rigor of instruction with adult ELLs, which includes greater emphasis on critical thinking in ELA classes, read the LINCS ELL Pro issue brief:

Meeting the Language Needs of Today’s Adult English Language Learner: Issue Brief (Parrish, 2015)

Optional Task: Consider what you think are the most compelling arguments for increasing the rigor of instruction. What are some practices that you could readily include in your classes or program?

page.title: Meet Aadan From Somalia
page.contents:
In Unit 1 of this module, we conducted a thorough analysis of Aadan's needs. The following were among those needs:

  • Supporting his children's academic achievement
  • Taking part in community activities and events that affect the well-being of his family
  • Handling conflict at work and using appropriate communication strategies
  • Increasing communication skills needed in customer service
  • Navigating workplace print documents
  • Earning his high school equivalency diploma

Adult ELLs know how to think critically; they just need to develop those skills and language needed for work and school contexts
(Parrish & Johnson, 2010).

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0020.mp3

Audio transcript


Perhaps the most compelling reason to work on critical thinking at all levels of instruction with adult ELLs is the real-world needs learners face. Aadan came to the United States 9 years ago as a refugee when he was 19 years old. Before that, he attended school for only 3 years in a refugee camp and has minimal literacy skills in his own language. He is married and has four school-aged children. He works as an attendant in a parking garage and attends English language classes three mornings a week. Because of his limited literacy skills, he has been placed in a beginning-level English class. At the same time, he has strong oral skills and is quite confident communicating with teachers and people in his community. His dream is to one day get a high school equivalency diploma.

Because Aadan has strong oral skills, teaching approaches that draw on that strength would benefit him greatly, using motivating content and topics. He needs exposure to and practice with analyzing and interpreting different text types: short prose, charts, and graphs. He needs the language for engaging in productive discussions at work and school, for example, adding to others’ ideas, elaborating or clarifying, or summarizing what he has heard. To meet his dream of attaining his high school equivalency, ultimately Aadan will need to summarize, paraphrase, and synthesize ideas from what he has read. He will need to evaluate the evidence presented and state an opinion about what he has read. For learners with limited prior formal schooling, we know it can take upwards of 10 to 15 years to develop this kind of academic thinking and language. Aadan possesses critical thinking skills. He has navigated systems in the United States, found work, and made decisions for his family. Now, he needs to work on those skills in classroom and work settings and he needs to start now!

page.title: Meet Carlos From Mexico
page.contents:
In Unit 1 of this module, we conducted a thorough analysis of Carlos's needs as well (analysis of Carlos's needs) and identified the following personal and professional goals:

Personal and Professional Goals:

  • Return to a job as a mathematics teacher
  • Move out of a lower-wage job in manufacturing to a job in teaching
  • Navigate the licensing processes for teachers in his state

Academic Goals:

  • Move up to the advanced college bridge course
  • Enroll in courses needed for teacher licensure to become a mathematics teacher
  • Prepare for state teacher examinations

Learners with prior formal schooling in their first language now need practice with critical thinking skills in English.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0030.mp3

Audio transcript


Carlos was a high school mathematics teacher in his country. Currently he works at a manufacturing company as he improves his English. He wants to be a teacher again and needs to work with his state to see if he meets licensure requirements. He almost certainly needs to take some education classes and pass state teacher examinations, but he feels like that is a long way off. Right now he is in a high-intermediate-level English language class in a large, urban, adult education program. He hasn’t scored high enough to be placed in the more advanced college bridge courses, but he thinks that’s what he needs to get ahead.

page.title: Carlos Needs Practice
page.contents:
Carlos needs practice with accessing academic texts. He needs to:

  • Recognize text organization
  • Summarize, paraphrase, synthesize ideas
  • Evaluate evidence
  • State an opinion about what he has read

Carlos also needs to be developing these strategies in his current English class. He needs to:

  • Employ multiple strategies for organizing information (graphic organizers, outlining) to show the relationships between concepts

Adult ELLs like Carlos and Aadan need rigorous instruction that includes higher-order and critical thinking skills in English.

Listen to Audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0040.mp3

Audio transcript


In addition to the academic skills needed for accessing complex texts outlined for Aadan, Carlos needs to identify and use resources (print, electronic, and human) to learn about the state licensing procedures. No doubt he will need to use appropriate documentation processes for tasks (filing forms, writing emails) when pursuing further education or applying for licensure down the road. Be sure to see the LINCS ESL Pro Module 2 on developing digital literacy. As he listens to lectures and reads academic materials, he will need to employ multiple strategies for organizing information (graphic organizers, outlining) to show the relationships between concepts. These vignettes highlight the importance of moving beyond basic skills with adult ELLs and including instruction that develops an academic and professional discourse, along with opportunities to apply higher-order and critical thinking skills. Now let’s explore what those are in Part 2.

You have reached the end of this lesson.  You may review any of the content in this lesson using the Lesson Menu on the left of the screen.

If you have finished viewing the lesson, (1) click the NEXT button on this screen to indicate completion in your progress tracker.  Then, (2) return to the home page to select your next activity.  Activities you have completed will be checked off in your progress tracker.
